title: Who will be elected governor of Mississippi in the 2019 gubernatorial election?
possible_answers: Jim Hood (Democrat) by a margin greater than 5.00% of the total vote
Jim Hood (Democrat) by a margin of 5.00% or less of the total vote
Tate Reeves (Republican) by a margin of 5.00% or less of the total vote
Tate Reeves (Republican) by a margin greater than 5.00% of the total vote
correct_answer: Tate Reeves (Republican) by a margin greater than 5.00% of the total vote
preds: Bases on the historical voting of the the state

A recent article by The Economist has again reminded me of the very real possibility that Jim Hood might win the popular vote but still lose the election.  Mississippi's constitution has Jim Crow-era provision that "statewide officers must win a majority of the popular vote and a majority of the 122 districts comprising the state’s House of Representatives. If no one wins a double-majority, the House may choose the governor." [1] I have thus assigned most of the ~15% chance that I give to a Hood popular vote victory to the "none of the above" option in which Hood wins the popular vote but Reeves is selected by the Republican majority in the House. I have increased this probability because, according to The Economist article, Tate Reeves has "refused to rule out letting the House decide." See my earlier post for more of my reasoning on this: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/901186 In any case, this race still leans Republican anyway [2] and the recent Trump rally in MS [3] will likely give Reeves a boost, so I am also increasing the likelihood of a popular vote Reeves victory. There are no new polls to incorporate into my analysis. [1] https://www.economist.com/united-states/2019/10/31/jim-crow-still-haunts-mississippis-politics
[2] https://cookpolitical.com/ratings/governor-race-ratings
[3] https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-rallies-mississippi-ahead-governor-race-days-impeachment/story?id=66692841

Reeves is now leading in the polls by just a few percentage points.  Moreover, Reeves also had $1 million more (translated to about 80 percent more)  to spend in the final weeks and Trump remains popular and impeachment unpopular.  Trump will also appear just prior to the election.    There are virtually no undecideds so the race will turn on turn out.   I did not find any information about voter enthusiasm by party relating to Mississippi or nationally after yesterday's impeachment vote.  Democrats still lead nationally.  Yet, interestingly, there was a slight uptick among Republican voters in favor of an impeachment inquiry.   Balancing the different factors, I think Reeves will win.

Current polls and an election system requireing majority vote and majority of House districts, before giving the vote to the House (currently controlled by the GOP).
From: https://www.wjtv.com/news/local-news/us-judge-not-blocking-multistep-mississippi-election-system/
"Mississippi’s 1890 constitution requires a statewide candidate to win a majority of the popular vote and a majority of the 122 state House districts. If nobody wins both, the election is decided by the House, and representatives are not obligated to vote as their districts did."

Mississippi voters will decide the only open-seat gubernatorial race of 2019 as Gov. Phil Bryant (R) is prevented by term limits from seeking re-election. State Attorney General Jim Hood (D), Lt. Gov. Tate Reeves (R), Bob Hickingbottom (Constitution), and David Singletary (I) are competing to succeed Bryant.  Hood was first elected state attorney general in 2003 and describes himself as a moderate, saying that he is a firearms owner and that he supports restrictions on abortion. Reeves—who was first elected lieutenant governor in 2011 after serving eight years as state treasurer—says that he has lowered taxes while decreasing Mississippi's debt.  Reeves defeated former state Supreme Court Chief Justice William Waller (R) in a runoff August 27 after no candidate won a majority of the vote in the Republican primary. Hood won the Democratic primary over seven other candidates. Three separate race tracking outlets have rated the race Leans Republican. Through September 30, Reeves had spent $13.0 million on his campaign and Hood spent $3.2 million. As of that date, Reeves had $3.3 million in cash on hand to Hood's $1.3 million. A mid-October poll conducted by Mason-Dixon Polling & Strategy had Reeves leading Hood within the margin of error—46% to 43%—with 11% of voters undecided. Candidates running for statewide office in Mississippi must win both a majority of the statewide vote and a majority of the 122 state House districts in order to win the election outright. If no candidate does both, the state House votes to decide the winner.  
VOTE JIMBO (hes a cousin)

Shifting a bit in favor of Reeves given the state's partisan lean, and his fundraising and polling advantages.

that the Trump machine is coming to town to campaign for Tom tells me Hood is putting up  good fight. Mississippi gubernatorial candidates Tate Reeves (R) and Jim Hood (D) debated for the second time in less than a week at the WCBI studio in Columbus Monday. As in the first debate, Reeves and Hood emphasized the differences in their education and fiscal policies. As in the October 10 debate, both candidates called for an increase in teacher pay. Reeves again accused Hood of being unable to fund his policy proposals without raising taxes, while Hood again accused Reeves of supporting policies which would benefit his campaign donors over the average citizen. With less than three weeks until the November 5 election, Donald Trump Jr. and Kimberly Guilfoyle announced Wednesday that they would headline a Reeves fundraiser outside Hattiesburg on October 24. Former Gov. Jeb Bush (R-Fla.) had held a fundraiser for Reeves on October 1.

It would seem Mississippi tends to vote,  in to power, candidates who have had relatively more positive limelight shed on themselves. Also, Lieutenant governors seem to have an advantage when they run for the governor's office. Furthermore, the demographics of the state favors republicans.

Slightly increasing the bins in which Tate Reeves wins the election in light of President Trump's recent endorsement of Reeves on Twitter - in the past, such public endorsements by Trump have provided Republican candidates with a "Trump bump."

The Republicans look strong in this state. Based on historical results I'd say the Republicans are about 70-30 favourites. But Hood seems to be popular and has done alright in polls. For this reason I'd say the election will be tighter than history suggests. I'd still say its about 60-40 Republicans though. And I still think a convincing Republican win is most likely (5%+).

Hood is popular in the state and has shown he can win solid statewide victories so I think he has a decent change. Reeves does not have an incumbency advantage but this is still Mississippi so I think he has a definite advantage.
12% for none of the above because of the point that JC4841 made below.

Looking at Mississippi and how Republicans have done in Southern states, its safe to say that it will be a Republican victory statewide for the Governorship. However with that being said, Democrats will pick up some seats in the State legislature and the anti Trump Democrats will show up in mass to make the race close. Even with a large democratic turnout the population demographics and cultural mindset of Mississippi combined with the large number of registered  Republicans it will still be Republican controlled at the end of the day.

In the past four gubernatorial elections, the Republican candidate has won by a margin of more than 5%.[1] The largest margin was in the most recent 2015 election, where the incumbent Republican governor (who is now term-limited and has endorsed Reeves) won by a 34-point margin.[2] President Trump won by an 18-point margin in 2016.[3] In 2018, Mississippi's incumbent Republican senator won re-election by a 19-point margin in a general election and Cindy Hyde-Smith won by a Senate special election by a 7-point margin despite notable missteps like joking about public hangings and suppressing the liberal vote.[4] Also, 2019 is not a presidential election year - in the past, Republicans have performed better in such years since overall turnout is lower. And finally, as others have pointed out, Mississippi is one of the most inelastic states in the country - meaning that we should take this base rate even more seriously.  On the other hand, this election is certain to be a lot closer than the base rate would suggest, given Jim Hood's popularity. Hood has won the past four elections for Attorney General by a margin of at least 10%. He seems unusually popular for a Democrat and has staked out a number of popular conservative positions on social issues like guns and abortion, which is likely to help in the election.  It should be noted that in order to win a gubernatorial general election, a candidate must "receive a majority in the popular vote and must win a majority of Mississippi's 122 state house districts. If no candidate fulfills both of these requirements, the Mississippi House of Representatives selects the winner. As of May 2019, Republicans held a 74-45 majority in the state house."[5] Though Hood has a fairly significant chance of winning the popular vote, it seems extremely unlikely that he will win a majority of state house districts given the state house make-up. I have assigned a significant probability to "none of the above" for the scenario in which Hood wins the popular vote but is not elected governor. @KitsonJ makes some good points about base rates favoring Reeves [1]. The latter is also somewhat ahead in most but not all polling [2]. We’d also have to consider the incumbent presidency effect, i.e. the party in opposition may have a slight advantage provided by backlash against the party of the sitting president. Since 1992, the Republicans have won 6 of the 7 gubernatorial elections in Mississippi. Of those 6 republican victories, 5 have been over the margin of 5%. The one Democratic party victory, in 1999 was won by the dem candidate by 1.1%. According to 538, the polling website, Mississippi is one of "of the most “inelastic” states in the country, meaning there aren’t a lot of swing voters" (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-the-house-districts-that-swing-the-most-and-least-with-the-national-mood/). Tate Reeves, the Republican candidate is broadly running on a low tax, 'look how well the economy is doing' platform. Given that the chances of a recession this year in the US is low (<5%) this is likely to hold as an argument. The Mississippi gubernatorial election is held in a non general or congressional election year, so I doubt there will be any significant impact on turnout. I'll be updating when we get polls closer to the election.
